title: Graph of Black Immigration - identify concepts

content.description:
Black Immigrants Admitted and Black Emigrants Departed: United States, 1899 to 1937

All values are approximate.

For the bar graph:

There are 38 bars representing Volume admitted each year.

Select Volume data from the bar graph are as follows:

1899: 500

1907: 5,000

1909: 4,250

1911: 6,750

1914: 8,500

1916: 4,500

1917: 9,500

1918: 5,500

1921: 9,500

1922: 5,000

1924: 12,000

1925: 1,250

1930: 1,500

1938: 300

For the line graph:

The following 2 lines are shown:

Net admissions

Departed

The Net admissions line data begin in 1908 and follow the trend of the bar graph, with values slightly lower than the values of the bars.

The Departed line begins in 1908 at 500, reaches a peak of 1,500 in 1922, then falls back to around 500 through 1937.
Winston James, “Explaining Afro-Caribbean Social Mobility in the United States: Beyond the Sowell Thesis,” Comparative Studies in Society and History 44, 4 (2002): 218-62, https://doi.org/10.1017/S0010417502000129.
content.question: The increase in Afro-Caribbean migration after 1925 is largely the result of which of the following?

choices.label: The repeal of anti-immigration laws restricting Afro-Caribbean migration into the United States
The number of previously established Afro-Caribbean communities in the Midwest and western United States
The decreased racial violence in Southern states that motivated many Afro-Caribbeans to immigrate to the United States
The weakened Caribbean economies resulting from the aftermath of the First World War

content.answer: The weakened Caribbean economies resulting from the aftermath of the First World War

skill.text: 1.A: Identify and explain course concepts, developments, and processes.
